case_vignette: A new mother brings in her 2-week-old son because of a painful itchy rash on his trunk. Vital signs are within normal limits. A basic chemistry panel reveal sodium 135 mmol/L, potassium 4.1 mmol/L, chloride 107 mmol/L, carbon dioxide 22, blood urea nitrogen 30 mg/dL, creatinine 1.1 mg/dL, and glucose 108 mg/dL. On physical examination of the newborn, there are confluent erythematous patches with tiny vesicles and scaling. His mother notes that she has been bathing the patient twice a day.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My baby has a painful itchy rash on his trunk.
How long has the rash been present?
The rash has been there for some time now.
Has your baby been experiencing any fever or discomfort along with the rash?
No fever, just the rash seems to make him uncomfortable.
Has your baby been exposed to any new soaps, lotions, or detergents recently?
I've been bathing him twice a day, but I didn't mention anything about new products.
Does anyone in your family have a history of eczema or allergic skin rashes?
The vignette doesn't provide any information about family history.
I understand. Is your baby currently taking any medications or has any new foods been introduced recently?
No new foods or medications have been introduced.
**Final Diagnosis:** Atopic Dermatitis
